Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Systematic Evaluation and Further Improvement of Present Broadband Radiative Transfer Modeling Capabilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The terrestrial climate system is sensitive to the radiation budget. Thus, accurate knowledge about the solar and thermal infrared radiation in the coupled atmosphere-ocean system is critical to robust climate study. An example of this sensitivity is the suggestion that a 1% decrease in the solar constant could lead to an ice age. The effect of doubling CO2 on radiative forcing is approximately 4 Wm-2, whereas uncertainties in radiation simulations due to, for example, insufficient knowledge about the optical properties of clouds, may be larger than this value. During the 1980s and 1990s, many researchers made substantial progress in developing and improving radiative transfer schemes used in general climate models (GCMs), and various intercomparisons of GCM radiation codes were published. Since that time, significant progress has been made in light scattering computational methods, in-situ measurements and laboratory studies of the optical and microphysical properties of clouds and aerosols, gaseous absorption line parameters and the water vapor continuum absorption, optical properties of various oceanic constituents, and the efficiency of numerical schemes for solving radiative transfer equations. There is a pressing need to incorporate the aforesaid progress into radiative transfer modeling capabilities. Moreover, the ocean and atmosphere are not coupled in many existing radiative transfer models. The scattering and absorption of radiation by oceanic water, dissolved organic matter (the so-called yellow substance), and phytoplankton have an influence in heating the uppermost water layers, and consequently affect thermal and dynamic properties such as the sea surface temperature and depth of the mixed atmosphere-ocean layer. The reflection of radiation by the oceans, including the effects of a wavy air-water interface and whitecap, can also affect the spectral characteristics and magnitude of radiation and, thus, the radiative heating and cooling rates in the atmosphere. The overarching goal is to systematically evaluate and further improve current radiative transfer modeling capabilities.

Intellectual Merit:
The outcomes of the study will include 1) systematic quantification of the potential errors/inaccuracies of the aforesaid radiative transfer models, 2) extension of the current radiative transfer modeling capabilities to an atmosphere-ocean coupled system, 3) implementation of spectrally consistent parameterizations of ice clouds and dust aerosols, and 4) development and implementation of a computationally efficient radiative transfer solver.

Broader Impacts:
The research effort will improve the radiative transfer package currently used in climate models, and be a valuable contribution to the atmospheric radiative transfer and climate study communities. Furthermore, the light scattering modeling and parameterization capabilities can find potential applications in other areas such as remote sensing of dust aerosol and ice cloud properties. The associated educational pursuits will focus on mentoring a postdoc researcher, training a graduate student, and developing teaching materials. This effort will contribute to training young researchers in the discipline of radiative transfer and light scattering that is a quite unique branch of atmospheric physics. Furthermore, the integration of RRTMG into classroom teaching will directly benefit the educational program in atmospheric sciences, particularly, in hands-on experience in atmospheric radiative transfer simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project "Collaborative Research:  Systematic Evaluation and Further Improvement of Present Broadband Radiative Transfer Modeling Capabilities", led by PIs Prof. Ping Yang of Texas A&M and Dr. Eli Mlawer of AER, allowed for a collaboration between two premier radiative transfer research groups. Prof. Yang's group is world renown for its knowledge of scattering techniques and condensate optical properties, and the AER group led by Dr. Mlawer develops radiative transfer models widely used in the community, including RRTMG and LBLRTM. This project was mainly focused on a) establishing the importance of including scattering in longwave (i.e. thermal radiative processes) radiative transfer calculations and b) developing efficient and accurate methods to compute longwave scattering and implementing these methods in fast radiation codes. Other accomplishments were related to related radiative transfer issues. All project accomplishments are expected to lead to improved weather and climate simulations.

We quantified flux and heating rate biases due to neglecting the scattering of LW radiation by clouds by using advanced cloud optical property models and satellite data to specify information about the atmosphere and clouds. One-year global simulations showed that the LW scattering decreases top-of-atmosphere (TOA) upward flux by 2.6 (~10% of the TOA cloud radiative effect) and and increases surface downward flux by 1.2 (~5%) W/m2.  Including LW scattering of clouds in simulations cools the tropopause approximately 0.018 K/d and heats the surface about 0.028 K/d. (Kuo et al., Impact of multiple scattering on longwave radiative transfer involving clouds, 2017).

In another study, a state-of-the-art scaling-adjustment scheme based on the similarity principle was developed and its ability to compute longwave scattering was evaluated in RRTM for many diverse atmosphere-cloud profiles. For each of the atmosphere-cloud profiles, we performed irradiance calculations with six schemes (no-scattering RRTM, benchmark scattering calculations with DISORT, the newly developed scaling-adjustment scheme, the scaling-adjustment scheme of Chou et al. (1999), and two scaling schemes). The errors in the TOA upward irradiance for the original neglect-scattering scheme were found to be considerable, with an overestimation up to 14 W m-2. The two optical thickness scaling schemes reduce the maximum overestimation to about 8 W m-2. The two adjustment schemes further reduce the overestimation to less than 2 W m-2. (Tang et al., Improvement of the simulation of cloud longwave scattering in broadband radiative transfer models, 2018).

We improved the original implementation of the Tang et al. scattering approximation for flux computations in the new radiation code RTE+RRTMGP. We first revised this approximation, which in Tang et al. (2018) assumed an isothermal layered atmosphere, to be consistent with a "linear-in-tau" approximation for the thermal source. We implemented this revised approach in RTE+RRTMGP and compared the results to reference scattering results using DISORT. Along with the Tang approximation, the 'no-scattering' and '2-streams' approximations (already in RTE) were also evaluated, and the accuracy and timing of the results compared. These results showed that the revised Tang approximation is a worthy alternative to 2-streams solution with a choice between:

  1. Faster (30%) with similar accuracy (1 quadrature angle)
  2. More accurate but 30% slower (2 quadrature angles)

Other results included:

1) We evaluated implementations of the δ-Eddington scattering for broadband shortwave net radiation fluxes at the top of the atmosphere and the surface that used different parameterizations of the forward fraction of scattering, including the square and cube of the asymmetry factor (using the Henyey-Greenstein phase function) and the fraction of the forward single-scattered intensity over the total single-scattered intensity. (Ren et al., Improved delta-Eddington approximation for optically thin clouds).

2) We analyzed a novel method to solve the vector radiative transfer equation after it is decomposed into forward and diffuse components. (Sun et al., An Improved Small-Angle Approximation for Forward Scattering and Its Use in a Fast Two-Component Radiative Transfer Method, 2016).

3) We performed an extensive analysis of the longwave calculations of two fast radiation codes, RRTMG and the Fu-Liou code, with reference calculations of LBLRTM coupled with DISORT. RRTMG has errors that can be as large as 2-4 W/m2 for downward flux and more than -1 W/m2 for upward. A leading cause of these errors is that the spectroscopic foundation for RRTMG is more than 10 years old while LBLRTM has many, more recent, updates. The Fu-Liou code has smaller surface flux errors than RTTMG, while RRTMG has smaller TOA flux error.

4) Modules were developed for RRTMGP to provide the capability to convert cloud physical properties to the cloud optical properties required by the model to perform cloudy radiative transfer for users who prefer not to do this conversion themselves. The new modules will allow users to provide cloud fraction, cloud liquid and ice water path and particle sizes and will return cloud optical depth, and if scattering is requested, cloud single scattering albedo and either asymmetry parameter or scattering phase function.
